FacilityName: Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Texas Operations Center

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Ice Cream and Frozen Dessert Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
2.0 Executive Summary



The Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Operations Center is located in northwest Houston, Texas at 4494 Campbell Road.  The site was originally established and owned by Borden Ice Cream in 1985 to manufacture ice cream related products.  The facility has been owned by Dreyer's since 1996.  Dreyer's manufactures ice cream under the Dreyer's and Edy's brand names for Texas and the southeastern U.S. at this facility.  The TXOC facility had gradually expanded over the years and today manufactures ice cream and stores a variety of ice cream related products such as frozen fruit bars, Nestle's chocolate covered ice cream bars, and ice cream related products from other manufacturers.  Products are shipped via trucking operations.



The Dreyer's TXOC facility is covered by the RMP regulation because it uses ammonia for refrigeration purposes in excess of the threshold quantity (max inventory approx. 55,000 lbs., normal operating level estimated to be approx 45,000 lbs).  Dreyer's extensively uses ammonia refrigeration to support the manufacture and storage of ice cream products.  The refrigeration system is a 

Two-stage system with screw compressors and achieves space temperatures as low as -40 degrees F.  Manufacturing operations are generally conducted indoors with some ammonia storage and evaporative condensers outdoors on the roof.



Ammonia is the only RMP-covered chemical on the site.  Other materials on site are either present in less than threshold quantities do not meet the flash point criteria, or are not listed in the RMP and PSM regulations.  The other materials at the site relate to the manufacturing of ice cream and Food & Drug Administration regulations that apply to the site.



The Dreyer's TXOC facility is an EPA Program Level 3 site and has an OSHA 1910.119 Process Safety Management Program in place that addresses all 14 PSM program elements.  According the Five Year Accident History, there have been no releases associated with ammonia

resulting in injuries, fatalities, or other damages.



The EPA and International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidance document, "Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis" (EPA 550-B-99-009), was used as a guide in preparing the Dreyer's RMP program, including, but not limited to, the development of worst case and alternate release scenarios.



After considering several scenarios, the worst case scenario selected was the failure of the largest vessel located on the roof.  This scenario was selected because it is the largest ammonia storage vessel in the plant and it is located outdoors with potential impact to offsite neighbors.  The EPA/IIAR guidance document tables and equations in Appendix 4B were used for the distance determination.



The alternate cast scenario was based on the facility's five-year accident history.  The largest release in the five-year accident history was selected and the duration of the release was shortened to allow the release to get offsite.  Releases over substantially longer time spans do not go offsite.  The EPA/IIAR guidance document tables and equations in Appendix 4B were used for the distance determination.



Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream TXOC is located in northwest Houston.  The area is a light industrial and warehouse district and adjacent to the Spring Branch residential area.  The area is part of the Cypress Fairbanks Independent School District (CFISD).  Schools impacted by the worst case scenario include two schools in southern CFISD, two schools in northern Spring Branch Independent School District, a community college, and two private schools in the northern part of Spring Branch.  The only major receptor is a park owned by the City of Houston located just west of the facility.  A hospital is located at the very edge of the 

Worst-case scenario circle.



Note that the Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream TXOC is shown slightly incorrect in Landview III mapping software.  Landview III was used to

help determine Dreyer's offsite receptors.  The TRI layer shows a Borden facility located on top of Campbell Road.  This filing goes back to the days of Borden ownership and the origin of this location is unknown.



Dreyer's TXOC has an Emergency Response Plan/Program in place to protect workers in case of an emergency.  This plan also includes coordination and response with offsite agencies in case of an emergency.



Dreyer's TXOC has several safeguards either already in place or are currently underway that would mitigate an ammonia release.  In addition, Dreyer's continually reviews opportunities to improve safety where deemed necessary.  Dreyer's is in the process of relocating ammonia piping from indoor releases of ammonia.  Located indoors, the ammonia compressor room is ventilated in accordance with IIAR standards.  Outdoor equipment is located on the roof, about 40-60 feet aboveground, with the exceptions noted below**.  The ammonia unloading line is located on the east side of the Dreyer's facility away from the public park.  Dreyer's TXOC does not use chlorine or other highly hazardous chemicals in its cooling water.  Dreyer's TXOC follows guidelines from the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration and OSHA's 29CFR1910.119 Process safety Management regulation.



** 

1. High pressure receiver (east side, on concrete pad 10' AGL)

2. Low temperature recirculator (west side, AGL)

3. Ammonia tank truck unloading line (east side, on concrete pad 10' AGL)
